elements.content: A series of compounds of composition A[CuI­(F4­TCNQII–)] (A = a quaternary ammonium or phosphonium cation, F4­TCNQII– = the dianionic form of 2,3,5,6-tetra­fluoro-7,7,8,8-tetra­cyano­quino­dimethane) have been synthesized and structurally characterized. In each structure, an anionic [CuI­(F4­TCNQII–)]− framework possessing the topology of PtS is formed with the Cu(I) center serving as a tetrahedral 4-connecting center and the F4­TCNQ2– anion acting as a planar 4-connecting unit. Although a PtS topology is observed for six different compounds, the anionic framework shows significant geometric variation depending upon the identity of the cation. Very similar structures are obtained when the organic cation is NMe4 +, NMe2­Pr2 +, or NMe2­Bu2 +. A distorted anionic structure possessing the same connectivity is generated when the cation is NEt4 +, and anionic frameworks with a different connectivity, but still related to PtS, are obtained when the much larger quaternary phosphonium cations are employed. Of interest in the structures containing quaternary phosphonium cations are π-stacking interactions involving phenyl groups of the cation and F4­TCNQ2– ligands. These face-to-face interactions between the electron-rich F4­TCNQ2– ligands and a phenyl group of the cation appear to be responsible for the color exhibited by these compounds.
elements.clean_text: A series of compounds of composition A[CuI(F4TCNQII-)] (A = a quaternary ammonium or phosphonium cation, F4TCNQII- = the dianionic form of 2,3,5,6-tetrafluoro-7,7,8,8-tetracyanoquinodimethane) have been synthesized and structurally characterized. In each structure, an anionic [CuI(F4TCNQII-)]- framework possessing the topology of PtS is formed with the Cu(I) center serving as a tetrahedral 4-connecting center and the F4TCNQ2- anion acting as a planar 4-connecting unit. Although a PtS topology is observed for six different compounds, the anionic framework shows significant geometric variation depending upon the identity of the cation. Very similar structures are obtained when the organic cation is NMe4 +, NMe2Pr2 +, or NMe2Bu2 +. A distorted anionic structure possessing the same connectivity is generated when the cation is NEt4 +, and anionic frameworks with a different connectivity, but still related to PtS, are obtained when the much larger quaternary phosphonium cations are employed. Of interest in the structures containing quaternary phosphonium cations are π-stacking interactions involving phenyl groups of the cation and F4TCNQ2- ligands. These face-to-face interactions between the electron-rich F4TCNQ2- ligands and a phenyl group of the cation appear to be responsible for the color exhibited by these compounds.

elements.content: The combination of tetrahedral Cu(I) centers with the dianionic form of 2,3,5,6-tetrafluoro-7,7,8,8-tetra­cyano­quino­di­methane (F4­TCNQ2−) in the presence of various organic cations leads to the formation of 3D anionic nets that are topologically related to platinum sulfide. The geometry of the anionic network is sensitive to the nature of the cation that is incorporated within the intersecting channels of the anionic network.
elements.clean_text: The combination of tetrahedral Cu(I) centers with the dianionic form of 2,3,5,6-tetrafluoro-7,7,8,8-tetracyanoquinodimethane (F4TCNQ2-) in the presence of various organic cations leads to the formation of 3D anionic nets that are topologically related to platinum sulfide. The geometry of the anionic network is sensitive to the nature of the cation that is incorporated within the intersecting channels of the anionic network.

elements.content: The planned construction in the early 90s of 3D coordination polymers with fully intended topologies and structures, based on prototypes, such as diamond, rutile, and PtS, demonstrated for the first time the feasibility and practicability of constructing an unlimited range of microporous framework solids resembling zeolites but with much greater compositional and structural diversity, promising useful properties that could be tailored. Attention was drawn to the likelihood that coordination polymers would provide “materials combining good or even high thermal, chemical and mechanical stability with unusually low density”. Over the past two decades, intense interest in microporous coordination networks, often referred to as MOFs, has produced a variety of stunningly beautiful structures promising useful applications.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The planned construction in the early 90s of 3D coordination polymers with fully intended topologies and structures, based on prototypes, such as diamond, rutile, and PtS, demonstrated for the first time the feasibility and practicability of constructing an unlimited range of microporous framework solids resembling zeolites but with much greater compositional and structural diversity, promising useful properties that could be tailored. Attention was drawn to the likelihood that coordination polymers would provide "materials combining good or even high thermal, chemical and mechanical stability with unusually low density". Over the past two decades, intense interest in microporous coordination networks, often referred to as MOFs, has produced a variety of stunningly beautiful structures promising useful applications.

elements.content: The results presented below constitute an extension of the earlier work with coordination polymers having the topology of PtS, whose structure was determined by Bannister and Hey in 1932 and has been clearly described by Wells. It consists of approximately square planar Pt(II) centers bound to four tetrahedral sulfide anions. Crystals of PtS are tetragonal, and when viewed along the a and b axes, hexagonal channels are apparent [Figure a and Figure S1 ()]. Linear strips formed by edge-shared PtS4 units form the floor and ceiling of the hexagonal channels; equivalent strips running normal to these strips run in a vertical direction. Along the unique c direction square channels are apparent with all PtS4 units viewed edge-on (Figure b).

elements.content: The synthesis and electronic properties of coordination polymers in which both the metal and the ligand carry unpaired electrons and/or are redox-active warrant detailed exploration because of the possibility of creating materials possessing unusual electronic and magnetic properties. Pioneering work conducted at DuPont in the 1950s and 1960s, concerned with the synthesis and properties of TCNQ (7,7,8,8-tetracyanoquinodimethane, Ia) and its derivatives aroused great and continuing interest. The ready accessibility of the radical anion, TCNQ•–, was demonstrated. By the use as starting materials of either TCNQ0 or TCNQ•–, large numbers of derivatives, purely organic as well as metal-containing, were synthesized in which the TCNQ component generally had an average oxidation state of minus one to zero and participated in some form of close π–π association.
elements.clean_text: The synthesis and electronic properties of coordination polymers in which both the metal and the ligand carry unpaired electrons and/or are redox-active warrant detailed exploration because of the possibility of creating materials possessing unusual electronic and magnetic properties. Pioneering work conducted at DuPont in the 1950s and 1960s, concerned with the synthesis and properties of TCNQ (7,7,8,8-tetracyanoquinodimethane, Ia) and its derivatives aroused great and continuing interest. The ready accessibility of the radical anion, TCNQ⋅-, was demonstrated. By the use as starting materials of either TCNQ0 or TCNQ⋅-, large numbers of derivatives, purely organic as well as metal-containing, were synthesized in which the TCNQ component generally had an average oxidation state of minus one to zero and participated in some form of close π-π association.

elements.content: Coordination networks with the PtS topology were deliberately constructed in the 90s in which the tetrahedral 4-connector was provided by Cu(I) and the planar 4-connector either by [Pt­(CN)4]2– or by appropriately substituted metalloporphyrins. Similar PtS-related networks in which the planar 4-connecting component was provided by the TCNQ•– radical anion appeared at the time eminently reasonable objectives and promised electronic/magnetic properties of outstanding interest, but all of our efforts in the early 90s to obtain such materials failed to afford products suitable for X-ray crystallography. It was recognized, however, in the middle 1990s that the structure of Ag­(TCNQ), reported 10 years earlier consists of two independent and interpenetrating nets with the PtS topology. We report below a family of TCNQ-related compounds that can be obtained in a form suitable for crystallographic studies, containing coordination networks that do have the intended PtS topology. Efforts by others in the 90s to generate PtS-related nets by combining tetracyanoethylene with CuI or AgI also failed, but these workers did succeed in obtaining a PtS-related network by the combination of CuI and 1,2,4,5-tetracyanobenzene. Interest in the deliberate construction of PtS-related coordination networks continues; recently, Zn2+ was used as the tetrahedral 4-connecting node and M­(CN)4 2– (M = Ni, Pd, Pt) as the planar 4-connecting node to generate intended PtS-related networks, two of which interpenetrate.

Similar PtS-related networks in which the planar 4-connecting component was provided by the TCNQ⋅- radical anion appeared at the time eminently reasonable objectives and promised electronic/magnetic properties of outstanding interest, but all of our efforts in the early 90s to obtain such materials failed to afford products suitable for X-ray crystallography. It was recognized, however, in the middle 1990s that the structure of Ag(TCNQ), reported 10 years earlier consists of two independent and interpenetrating nets with the PtS topology. We report below a family of TCNQ-related compounds that can be obtained in a form suitable for crystallographic studies, containing coordination networks that do have the intended PtS topology. Efforts by others in the 90s to generate PtS-related nets by combining tetracyanoethylene with CuI or AgI also failed, but these workers did succeed in obtaining a PtS-related network by the combination of CuI and 1,2,4,5-tetracyanobenzene. Interest in the deliberate construction of PtS-related coordination networks continues; recently, Zn2+ was used as the tetrahedral 4-connecting node and M(CN)4 2- (M = Ni, Pd, Pt) as the planar 4-connecting node to generate intended PtS-related networks, two of which interpenetrate.

elements.content: The present report is focused on the use of a TCNQ-derived dianion as the planar 4-connecting node for PtS-related networks. The first structurally characterized example of a salt containing the TCNQ2– dianion, IIa, was [CoIII­(C5­Me5)2 +]2­[TCNQ2–] obtained by reduction of TCNQ0 with [CoII­(C5­Me5)2]. Similar reaction of F4TCNQ, Ib, with decamethylferrocene yields a compound containing discrete F4­TCNQ2– dianions, (IIb), of composition {[FeIII­(C5­Me5)2]+}2­[F4­TCNQ2–], in a form suitable for single-crystal X-ray structural determination. A report of black air-sensitive materials described as metal derivatives of TCNQ2– had appeared earlier, but X-ray structural confirmation was not available. Some nonpolymeric vanadium complexes of TCNQ2– have been crystallographically characterized. In 2005, a family of structurally uncharacterized M­(TCNQ) n magnets (M = Mn, Fe, Co, Ni) of variable compositions were reported. The first crystallographically characterized coordination polymer of TCNQ2– was described by Kitagawa and co-workers, the source of the dianion, mysteriously at the time, being the monoanion radical TCNQ•–. Working with the tetrafluoro derivative, Dunbar and co-workers observed a similar generation of the dianion from the monoanion-radical starting material in a Mn-based coordination polymer.

The first structurally characterized example of a salt containing the TCNQ2- dianion, IIa, was [CoIII(C5Me5)2 +]2[TCNQ2-] obtained by reduction of TCNQ0 with [CoII(C5Me5)2]. Similar reaction of F4TCNQ, Ib, with decamethylferrocene yields a compound containing discrete F4TCNQ2- dianions, (IIb), of composition {[FeIII(C5Me5)2]+}2[F4TCNQ2-], in a form suitable for single-crystal X-ray structural determination. A report of black air-sensitive materials described as metal derivatives of TCNQ2- had appeared earlier, but X-ray structural confirmation was not available. Some nonpolymeric vanadium complexes of TCNQ2- have been crystallographically characterized. In 2005, a family of structurally uncharacterized M(TCNQ) n  magnets (M = Mn, Fe, Co, Ni) of variable compositions were reported. The first crystallographically characterized coordination polymer of TCNQ2- was described by Kitagawa and co-workers, the source of the dianion, mysteriously at the time, being the monoanion radical TCNQ⋅-. Working with the tetrafluoro derivative, Dunbar and co-workers observed a similar generation of the dianion from the monoanion-radical starting material in a Mn-based coordination polymer.

elements.content: A very general and convenient route to a wide range of new compounds based on TCNQ2–, both coordination polymers and nonpolymeric systems, was recently introduced, in which this dianion is generated by deprotonation of the reduced (i.e., hydrogenated) form of TCNQ, represented here as TCNQH2, IIIa. It is significant that, in the presence of the metal cation to which the TCNQ2– dianion is to be attached, a base as weak as the acetate ion is sufficient to remove both protons from TCNQH2, making possible very simple synthetic procedures. Although electrochemically generated TCNQ2– in solution was long ago reported to be very air-sensitive, the incorporation of this dianion into coordination networks appears to afford significant stabilization. Nevertheless, certain solids obtained by the TCNQH2 route containing discrete, uncoordinated TCNQ2– ions prove also to be air-stable. Recently, the synthesis (from Li+F4­TCNQ•–) and the X-ray structure of (NPr4 +)2­(F4­TCNQ2–) were reported by Bond, Martin, and co-workers. The same group reported an electrochemical investigation of transition-metal F4­TCNQ2– derivatives indicating that F4­TCNQ2– is more stable than the unsubstituted TCNQ2– with respect to oxidation. This stability with respect to oxidation presumably reflects the electron-withdrawing effect of the fluorine atoms bound to the aromatic ring.
elements.clean_text: A very general and convenient route to a wide range of new compounds based on TCNQ2-, both coordination polymers and nonpolymeric systems, was recently introduced, in which this dianion is generated by deprotonation of the reduced (i.e., hydrogenated) form of TCNQ, represented here as TCNQH2, IIIa. It is significant that, in the presence of the metal cation to which the TCNQ2- dianion is to be attached, a base as weak as the acetate ion is sufficient to remove both protons from TCNQH2, making possible very simple synthetic procedures. Although electrochemically generated TCNQ2- in solution was long ago reported to be very air-sensitive, the incorporation of this dianion into coordination networks appears to afford significant stabilization. Nevertheless, certain solids obtained by the TCNQH2 route containing discrete, uncoordinated TCNQ2- ions prove also to be air-stable. Recently, the synthesis (from Li+F4TCNQ⋅-) and the X-ray structure of (NPr4 +)2(F4TCNQ2-) were reported by Bond, Martin, and co-workers. The same group reported an electrochemical investigation of transition-metal F4TCNQ2- derivatives indicating that F4TCNQ2- is more stable than the unsubstituted TCNQ2- with respect to oxidation. This stability with respect to oxidation presumably reflects the electron-withdrawing effect of the fluorine atoms bound to the aromatic ring.

elements.content: The TCNQH2 approach affords a family of coordination polymers containing sheets of composition [MII­(TCNQII–)] with various substituted N-heterocycles coordinated in a trans fashion on opposite sides of the sheet. 4,4′-Bipyridine and related bridging ligands are able to act as pillars, linking sheet to sheet to form 3D networks containing channels. In similar pillared structures containing TCNQ2–, obtained independently by Kitagawa et al., the source of TCNQ2– was the monoanion/radical in the presence of ascorbic acid. The TCNQH2 approach also affords a family of 3D networks of composition [(MII)2­(TC­NQII–)3]2– generating spacious channels of a hexagonal cross section, where the countercations reside. Other structural classes of TCNQ2–-containing coordination networks, to be reported, can also be obtained by the TCNQH2 route. As mentioned above, the TCNQ components in earlier coordination polymers generally carry a formal charge of −1 or less, and are generally involved in close π–π contacts, whereas the TCNQ2– components of networks obtained via the TCNQH2 approach are well separated from each other. The roughly planar TCNQ2– components are thus, in principle, accessible from either side to interaction with various reagents introduced into the channels. One of our longer term objectives is to intercalate oxidants into TCNQ2–-based coordination polymers without disrupting the original connectivity, thereby generating networks in which all or a fraction of the TCNQ units, initially in the 2– state, have formally been oxidized to the 1– radical state, while remaining free of π–π contactsunusual circumstances for the TCNQ–• radical anion.

In similar pillared structures containing TCNQ2-, obtained independently by Kitagawa et al., the source of TCNQ2- was the monoanion/radical in the presence of ascorbic acid. The TCNQH2 approach also affords a family of 3D networks of composition [(MII)2(TCNQII-)3]2- generating spacious channels of a hexagonal cross section, where the countercations reside. Other structural classes of TCNQ2--containing coordination networks, to be reported, can also be obtained by the TCNQH2 route. As mentioned above, the TCNQ components in earlier coordination polymers generally carry a formal charge of -1 or less, and are generally involved in close π-π contacts, whereas the TCNQ2- components of networks obtained via the TCNQH2 approach are well separated from each other. The roughly planar TCNQ2- components are thus, in principle, accessible from either side to interaction with various reagents introduced into the channels. elements.content: The results presented below are concerned with the deliberate construction of a family of PtS-related networks in which the 4-connecting planar component is provided by F4­TCNQ2– (IIb), the role of the tetrahedral component being played by CuI.

elements.content: Commercially available reagents employed in the synthesis of the compounds reported were used without further purification. Microanalyses were performed by either the Microanalytical Unit in the Research School of Chemistry at the Australian National University or the Campbell Microanalytical Laboratory at the University of Otago, NZ.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Procedures

Commercially available reagents employed in the synthesis of the compounds reported were used without further purification. Microanalyses were performed by either the Microanalytical Unit in the Research School of Chemistry at the Australian National University or the Campbell Microanalytical Laboratory at the University of Otago, NZ.

elements.content:
F4­TCNQ­H2 (IIIb) was prepared according to the literature method.

Synthesis of NMe<sub>4</sub>­[Cu<sup>I</sup>­(F<sub>4</sub>­TCNQ<sup>II–</sup>) (<bold>1</bold>), NMe<sub>2</sub>­Pr<sub>2</sub>­[Cu<sup>I</sup>­(F<sub>4</sub>­TCNQ<sup>II–</sup>)] (<bold>2</bold>), NMe<sub>2</sub>­Bu<sub>2</sub>­[Cu<sup>I</sup>­(F<sub>4</sub>­TCNQ<sup>II–</sup>)] (<bold>3</bold>), and NEt<sub>4</sub>­[Cu<sup>I</sup>­(F<sub>4</sub>­TCNQ<sup>II–</sup>)] (<bold>4</bold>)

Compound 1 was prepared by dissolving [Cu­(Me­CN)4]­ClO4 (15.3 mg, 0.047 mmol) in MeCN (3 mL) and mixing this with a solution of Li­(OAc)·2H2O (82.5 mg, 0.81 mmol) and tetramethylammonium bromide (72.3 mg, 0.47 mmol) in EtOH (3 mL). The solution was then allowed to slowly diffuse into a solution of F4­TCNQ­H2 (13 mg, 0.047 mmol) in DMSO (1 mL). Crystals for single-crystal analysis were transferred directly from the mother liquor to a protective oil. The product was filtered and air-dried. Yield: 5.5 mg, 28%. IR (KBr): 2184, 2148, 1491, 1233, 1146, 962, 794, 544 cm–1. Anal. Calcd for C16H15­CuF4­N5O0.5 (1·0.5 H2O): C, 45.45; H, 3.10; N, 16.56. Found: C, 45.22; H, 3.24; N, 16.45%. Compounds 2, 3, and 4 were prepared via a similar method, but with 0.47 mmol of the appropriate tetraalkylammonium salt. Yield of 2: 2.7 mg, 12%. IR (KBr): 2185, 2147, 1486, 1231, 1143, 962, 792, 542 cm–1. Anal. Calcd for C20H20­CuF4­N5 (2): C, 51.12; H, 4.29; N, 14.90. Found: C, 50.78; H, 4.41; N, 14.62%. Yield of 3: 5.5 mg, 24%. IR (KBr): 2187, 2154, 1485, 1232, 1142, 961, 792, 540 cm–1. Anal. Calcd for C22H24­CuF4­N5 (3) C, 53.06; H, 4.86; N, 14.06. Found: C, 53.04; H, 5.05; N, 14.03%. Yield of 4·H2O: 2.5 mg, 11%. IR (KBr): 2178, 2135, 1487, 1224, 1147, 961, 791, 550 cm–1. Anal. Calcd for C20H22­CuF4­N5O (4·H2O) C, 49.22; H, 4.54; N, 14.35. Found: C, 48.94; H, 3.85; N, 14.29%.

elements.content: Single X-ray structural determinations were performed using an Oxford Diffraction Supernova diffractometer equipped with CuKα radiation. Crystals were transferred directly from the mother liquor to a protective oil before being placed on the diffractometer. All data were measured at 130 K. The structures were solved and refined using SHELX97 within the WinGX system of programs. For compounds 2·3EtOH and 3·2EtOH, the cations and guest solvent molecules lying within the channels were found to be highly disordered and could not be satisfactorily modeled. As a consequence, the SQUEEZE routine within PLATON was employed to generate data sets in which the contribution of the disordered species to the diffraction data was subtracted, generating modified data sets that were used in the refinement. For each of these two compounds, the estimation of the number of ethanol molecules included in the formula was based upon the void volume calculated using SQUEEZE. Crystal and refinement data are presented in Table .
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structures

Single X-ray structural determinations were performed using an Oxford Diffraction Supernova diffractometer equipped with CuKα radiation. Crystals were transferred directly from the mother liquor to a protective oil before being placed on the diffractometer. All data were measured at 130 K. The structures were solved and refined using SHELX97 within the WinGX system of programs. For compounds 2⋅3EtOH and 3⋅2EtOH, the cations and guest solvent molecules lying within the channels were found to be highly disordered and could not be satisfactorily modeled. As a consequence, the SQUEEZE routine within PLATON was employed to generate data sets in which the contribution of the disordered species to the diffraction data was subtracted, generating modified data sets that were used in the refinement. For each of these two compounds, the estimation of the number of ethanol molecules included in the formula was based upon the void volume calculated using SQUEEZE. Crystal and refinement data are presented in Table .

Spectroscopic Measurements

IR spectra were recorded on a Bruker Tensor 27 FTIR spectrometer using KBr discs. Reflectance spectra were recorded on ground solid samples on a Thermo Scientific Evolution 220 UV-visible spectrophotometer.

elements.content: Crystals of NMe4­[CuI­(F4­TCNQII–)]·0.5 H2O (1·0.5 H2O), NMe2­Pr2­[CuI­(F4­TCNQII–)]·3EtOH (2·3EtOH), NMe2­Bu2­[CuI­(F4­TCNQII–)]·2EtOH (3·2EtOH), and NEt4­[CuI­(F4­TCNQII–)]·DMSO (4·DMSO) were synthesized by allowing a solution containing Cu(I), a weak base, and an organic cation to diffuse slowly into a DMSO solution of F4TCNQH2. The LiOAc plays the role of a weak base and is required to deprotonate F4TCNQH2. PPh4­[CuI­(F4­TCNQII–)]·0.5 DMF (5·0.5 DMF) was prepared via a similar route except that 2,6-lutidine was employed as the base and the F4­TCNQH2 was dissolved in DMF. In the case of PMe­Ph3­[CuI­(F4­TCNQII–)]·DMF (6·DMF), LiOAc and PMe­Ph3­Br were dissolved in MeOH and added to a benzonitrile solution of CuI­ClO4, which was then allowed to diffuse into a DMF solution of F4­TCNQ­H2.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystals of NMe4[CuI(F4TCNQII-)]⋅0.5 H2O (1⋅0.5 H2O), NMe2Pr2[CuI(F4TCNQII-)]⋅3EtOH (2⋅3EtOH), NMe2Bu2[CuI(F4TCNQII-)]⋅2EtOH (3⋅2EtOH), and NEt4[CuI(F4TCNQII-)]⋅DMSO (4⋅DMSO) were synthesized by allowing a solution containing Cu(I), a weak base, and an organic cation to diffuse slowly into a DMSO solution of F4TCNQH2. The LiOAc plays the role of a weak base and is required to deprotonate F4TCNQH2. PPh4[CuI(F4TCNQII-)]⋅0.5 DMF (5⋅0.5 DMF) was prepared via a similar route except that 2,6-lutidine was employed as the base and the F4TCNQH2 was dissolved in DMF. In the case of PMePh3[CuI(F4TCNQII-)]⋅DMF (6⋅DMF), LiOAc and PMePh3Br were dissolved in MeOH and added to a benzonitrile solution of CuIClO4, which was then allowed to diffuse into a DMF solution of F4TCNQH2.

elements.content: Despite the diversity that is apparent within the series of structures reported here, there are structural features common to all. First, in each case, the Cu(I) center has a tetrahedral coordination geometry formed by four nitrogen centers belonging to four distinct F4­TCNQ2– units. Second, each F4­TCNQ2– unit is bound to four Cu(I) centers that lie at the corners of a rectangle. It is noted that, while the atoms of the ligand lie close to the plane of this CuI 4­(F4­TCNQII–) unit, the aromatic ring is often found to be slightly inclined to the plane of the rectangle defined by the four Cu(I) centers. In describing the following structures, it is convenient to refer to “the short edge” and the “the long edge” of the rectangle when considering the relative orientations of the F4­TCNQ2– anions. In each of the structures, the F4­TCNQ2– anion serves as the planar node in the PtS toplogy while the Cu(I) center acts as the tetrahedral node.

First, in each case, the Cu(I) center has a tetrahedral coordination geometry formed by four nitrogen centers belonging to four distinct F4TCNQ2- units. Second, each F4TCNQ2- unit is bound to four Cu(I) centers that lie at the corners of a rectangle. It is noted that, while the atoms of the ligand lie close to the plane of this CuI 4(F4TCNQII-) unit, the aromatic ring is often found to be slightly inclined to the plane of the rectangle defined by the four Cu(I) centers. In describing the following structures, it is convenient to refer to "the short edge" and the "the long edge" of the rectangle when considering the relative orientations of the F4TCNQ2- anions. In each of the structures, the F4TCNQ2- anion serves as the planar node in the PtS toplogy while the Cu(I) center acts as the tetrahedral node.

elements.content: Crystals of NMe4­[CuI­(F4­TCNQII–)]·0.5 H2O (1·0.5 H2O) are tetragonal and crystallize in the space group P42/mmc. Interestingly, this is the same space group as that found for PtS itself and reflects the high symmetry of the structure, which is depicted in Figure . Almost planar F4­TCNQ2– dianions are bound to four tetrahedral Cu(I) centers, which, in turn, are bound to four F4­TCNQ2– dianions. Although the four Cu(I) centers bound to a single F4­TCNQ2– dianion are coplanar, the aromatic ring exhibits a small degree of rotational disorder around the axis of the F4TCNQ2– dianion, which passes through the methanide carbon atoms. The Cu(I) centers are in a tetrahedral environment with N–Cu–N angles in the range of 107.4(2)–110.5(1)°. The Cu–N bonds are all identical with a bond length of 1.980(3) Å.

elements.content: Structure of NMe4­[Cu­(F4­TCNQII–)]·0.5H2O (1·0.5H2O). Stick representations of the anionic [CuF4­TCNQII–]− framework viewed from an angle close to (a) the b axis and (b) the a axis. The F4­TCNQII– ligands are represented by blue connections; Cu–N bonds are represented by red connections. Ball and stick representations viewed from an angle close to (c) the unique c axis and (d) the b axis showing the location of the NMe4 + cations and solvent within the elongated hexagonal channel; the NMe4 cations are shown occupying half the equivalent sites over which they are disordered. Color codes for spheres: Cu, blue; F, green; O, red; N, light blue; C, black; H, pink.

elements.content: The anionic network possesses a number of notable structural features. First, as is apparent in Figure , the F4­TCNQ2– ligands lie in two distinct orientations, the mean planes of which are normal to each other. For each orientation of the F4­TCNQ2– units, the axes that pass through pairs of methanide carbon centers are parallel with the c axis. As expected, given the adoption of a tetragonal space group, views of the network parallel to the a and b axes are similar and indicate channels with an elongated hexagonal cross section. The channel width as defined by the separation between the methanide carbons that lie at opposing vertices across the channel is 16.37 Å; the separation between the “floor and ceiling” of the hexagonal channels corresponds to the a cell dimension of 7.3888(2) Å. When viewed along the c axis, square channels are apparent with the planes of all F4TCNQ2– units parallel with this direction. The cross-sectional dimensions of the square channel, defined by the separation between Cu(I) centers, correspond to the unit cell dimensions in the a and b directions (Figure c). Inspection of Figure c indicates that the aromatic ring is tilted slightly out of the plane defined by the four Cu(I) centers bound to any one F4­TCNQ2– unit; for simplicity, a second symmetry-related orientation of the aromatic ring has been omitted from the representations in Figure .

First, as is apparent in Figure , the F4TCNQ2- ligands lie in two distinct orientations, the mean planes of which are normal to each other. For each orientation of the F4TCNQ2- units, the axes that pass through pairs of methanide carbon centers are parallel with the c axis. As expected, given the adoption of a tetragonal space group, views of the network parallel to the a and b axes are similar and indicate channels with an elongated hexagonal cross section. The channel width as defined by the separation between the methanide carbons that lie at opposing vertices across the channel is 16.37 Å; the separation between the "floor and ceiling" of the hexagonal channels corresponds to the a cell dimension of 7.3888(2) Å. When viewed along the c axis, square channels are apparent with the planes of all F4TCNQ2- units parallel with this direction. The cross-sectional dimensions of the square channel, defined by the separation between Cu(I) centers, correspond to the unit cell dimensions in the a and b directions (Figure c). Inspection of Figure c indicates that the aromatic ring is tilted slightly out of the plane defined by the four Cu(I) centers bound to any one F4TCNQ2- unit; for simplicity, a second symmetry-related orientation of the aromatic ring has been omitted from the representations in Figure .

elements.content: The tetramethylammonium ions are located within the hexagonal channels and are disordered over symmetry-related positions; the occupancy of any given cation site is 50%. Within the channel indicated in Figure d, the methyl groups extending toward the center of the hexagonal channel are directed up and down with these methyl carbon and nitrogen atoms lying on a plane that lies between pairs of F4­TCNQ2– units located above and below the cation. Only half the tetramethylammonium cations are located in the hexagonal channels running parallel to the a axis. The remaining cations are, in fact, symmetry-related to the first type of cation and are located in the hexagonal channels that extend along the b direction. When viewed along the c axis, the nitrogen atoms of the cations are not located within the center of the square channels but rather lie in the channel walls along the axes that pass through the methanide carbon atoms (see the ).

elements.content: Following the assignment of the atoms within the anionic network and the cation, a peak of residual electron density was located that is consistent with the presence of disordered water. The peak, which is sandwiched between aromatic rings, lies close to the intersection of the axes that pass through the hexagonal and square channels. This peak was assigned as an oxygen atom of a water molecule with 50% occupancy.

elements.content: Very similar anionic networks are generated when NMe2­Pr2 + and NMe2­Bu2 + are used in place of NMe4 +. This similarity is highlighted by the adoption of the same space group and similar cell dimensions (Table ) for the three structures. Although the anionic networks in the NMe2­Pr2 + and NMe2­Bu2 + structures are clearly defined, the cation and accompanying solvent molecules in each structure show a high degree of disorder and, as a consequence, could not be satisfactorily modeled.

elements.content: Crystals of NEt4­[CuI­(F4­TCNQII–)]·DMSO (Figure ) are orthorhombic, and although the PtS topology is again observed, the structure shows an interesting contrast to the high symmetry ones described above. The Cu–N distances are very similar to those reported above and lie in the range of 1.980(2)–2.001(2) Å. However, the N–Cu–N angles (104.58(13)–112.93(10)°) reveal that the tetrahedral Cu(I) coordination environment is more distorted in the NEt4 + structure. Elongated hexagonal channels are again apparent from two different directions [Figure a and Figure S3 ()]. The long axes of all F4­TCNQ2– dianions, which lie in two distinct orientations, are parallel to each other, but the planes of the two orientations, defined by the four Cu(I) centers bound to a single F4­TCNQ2– unit, are inclined to each other at an angle of 81°, whereas, in the P42/mmc structures, they are inclined at an angle of 90° to each other. As a result, when the structure is viewed along the direction parallel to the long axes of the F4­TCNQ2– units (Figure b), the channels have a rhombic cross section, which is in contrast to the corresponding square channels in the tetragonal structures. Elongated hexagonal channels closely resemble the channels found in the previously described structures; however, the F4­TCNQ2– units that form the floor of the channels do not lie directly underneath the F4­TCNQ2– units in the ceiling, as is apparent in Figure b.
elements.clean_text: Crystals of NEt4[CuI(F4TCNQII-)]⋅DMSO (Figure ) are orthorhombic, and although the PtS topology is again observed, the structure shows an interesting contrast to the high symmetry ones described above. The Cu-N distances are very similar to those reported above and lie in the range of 1.980(2)-2.001(2) Å. However, the N-Cu-N angles (104.58(13)-112.93(10)°) reveal that the tetrahedral Cu(I) coordination environment is more distorted in the NEt4 + structure. Elongated hexagonal channels are again apparent from two different directions [Figure a and Figure S3 ()]. The long axes of all F4TCNQ2- dianions, which lie in two distinct orientations, are parallel to each other, but the planes of the two orientations, defined by the four Cu(I) centers bound to a single F4TCNQ2- unit, are inclined to each other at an angle of 81°, whereas, in the P42/mmc structures, they are inclined at an angle of 90° to each other. As a result, when the structure is viewed along the direction parallel to the long axes of the F4TCNQ2- units (Figure b), the channels have a rhombic cross section, which is in contrast to the corresponding square channels in the tetragonal structures. Elongated hexagonal channels closely resemble the channels found in the previously described structures; however, the F4TCNQ2- units that form the floor of the channels do not lie directly underneath the F4TCNQ2- units in the ceiling, as is apparent in Figure b.

elements.content: The tetraethylammonium cation is ordered in this structure with its location alternating from one side to the other along the length of the hexagonal channel. An orientationally disordered DMSO molecule is located alongside each of the NEt4 + cations, as shown in Figure c. Symmetry-related channels run at an angle of 81° to these parallel channels.

elements.content: When the large bulky cation tetraphenylphosphonium is used in place of the quaternary ammonium cations, a PtS structure is again the result, but the structure shows significant differences from those above. The compound, PPh4­[CuI­(F4­TCNQII–)]0.5DMF (5·0.5DMF), has Cu–N distances in the range of 1.9577(15)–2.0067(15) Å, and while the coordination environment would still be described as tetrahedral, the N–Cu–N angles of 99.28(6)–117.22(7)° span a larger range than that found for the tetraalkylammonium compounds. A key difference, however, between this structure and the tetraalkylammonium structures relates to the orientation of the F4­TCNQ2– anions. The long axes of the F4­TCNQ2– anions are no longer all parallel, as indicated in Figure a. As a result of this arrangement, the elongated hexagonal channels, which run in mutually perpendicular (or almost mutually perpendicular) directions in the tetra­alkyl­ammonium compounds, are no longer apparent. In the PPh4 + structure, the different orientations of the F4TCNQ2– ligands lead to channels with a “floor to ceiling” separation corresponding to the long edge of the Cu4­(F4­TCNQII–) unit instead of the short edge. Running almost perpendicular are hexagonal channels (Figure b) that bear some resemblance to the hexagonal channels that were identified in the tetra­alkyl­ammonium structures; however, they are not as elongated and have a smaller cross-sectional area. When viewed along the direction approximately edge-on to both orientations of the F4­TCNQ2– anions (Figure c), channels with an approximately rectangular cross section are apparent.

elements.content: The contrasting structure obtained with the use of PPh4 + appears to be a consequence of the cation size. The size and conformational flexibility of the tetraalkylammonium cations mean that they can be accommodated in channels in which the floor-to-ceiling separation corresponds to the short edge of the F4­TCNQ2– unita separation of approximately 7.4 Å. The size of the PPh4 + cation in addition to its limited conformational flexibility does not allow it to occupy the types of channels depicted in Figure a. Through reorientation of half of the F4­TCNQ2– anions, larger channels are produced that can house PPh4 + cations. Along the length of the channel, which extends in the c direction, the PPh4 + cations occupy one of four symmetry-related positions (Figure d). It is noted that the PPh4 + cations within a single channel form contacts with three other PPh4 + cations but are well separated from PPh4 + cations that lie in parallel channels. A phenyl group from each PPh4 + cation participates in π-stacking interactions and is sandwiched between F4­TCNQ2– units that are 7.5 Å apart; the closest separation between non-hydrogen atoms in the phenyl group and the F4­TCNQ2– ligand is 3.33 Å. These π-stacking interactions extend right along the direction parallel to the c axis (Figure e).

elements.content: The final compound considered in this report has the composition PMe­Ph3­[CuI­(F4­TCNQII–)]·DMF (6·DMF). The anionic [CuI­(F4­TCNQII–)] framework resembles that found in PPh4­[CuI­(F4­TCNQII–)]; however, the framework is somewhat more distorted, as can be seen upon inspection of Figure a–c. Cu–N distances (1.967(2)–2.043(2) Å) and N–Cu–N angles (99.32(8)–119.00(8)°) are similar to those found in the PPh4 + structure and are consistent with a significantly distorted tetrahedral environment. The large channels are occupied by PMePh3 + cations that are located on one of two symmetry-related positions along the channels that are parallel to the a axis (Figure d). Also located in the channels are DMF molecules, which occupy symmetry-related positions. Unlike the PPh4 + structure, the cations within the channels do not make close contact with each other; the only association between PMePh3 + cations is limited to self-complementary edge-to-face interactions between pairs of PMePh3 + cations residing in neighboring parallel channels. Despite the difference in the relative arrangement of the quaternery phosphonium cations, a feature of both structures is the location of one of the phenyl rings from each cationic unit between pairs of F4­TCNQ2– anions; the closest separation between non-hydrogen atoms is 3.36 Å. In both cases, this interaction appears to anchor the cation in place and leads to the formation of an infinite stack of alternating F4­TCNQ2– dianions and phenyl rings belonging to quaternary phosphonium cations (Figure e). In addition, in each of the quaternary phosphonium structures, a second phenyl ring forms a weak π–π interaction with a F4­TCNQ2– unit that forms part of the floor (or ceiling) of the large channel (Figures d and d).

elements.content: Interestingly, the PPh4 + and PMe­Ph3 + compounds are colored (dark green and yellow, respectively), whereas the compounds incorporating the tetraalkylammonium cations are much paler. The UV–vis reflectance spectra recorded on the solid samples show broad maxima in the reflected light at 560 (5) and 580 (6) nm (see the ). We believe that charge-transfer interactions involving the electron-rich F4­TCNQ2– units and phenyl rings of the cation are responsible for the intense color exhibited by the PPh4 + and PMePh3 + compounds. Investigations of charge-transfer interactions between F4­TCNQ2– anions and various cations are part of an extended study that is currently underway.

elements.content: In its neutral form, F4­TCNQ (Ib) is a planar molecule, which is unsurprising given the quinonoid nature of the molecule. In contrast, F4­TCNQ2– (IIb), with formal single bonds from the aromatic ring to the para substituents, is not required to be planar, but nevertheless, in the structures involving this species, the four Cu(I) centers bound to the dianion are located at the corners, or close to the corners of a rectangle (even though the aromatic ring may be slightly inclined to the mean plane of the four Cu(I) centers).

In contrast, F4TCNQ2- (IIb), with formal single bonds from the aromatic ring to the para substituents, is not required to be planar, but nevertheless, in the structures involving this species, the four Cu(I) centers bound to the dianion are located at the corners, or close to the corners of a rectangle (even though the aromatic ring may be slightly inclined to the mean plane of the four Cu(I) centers).

elements.content: Although all the anionic networks described in this report are topologically related to PtS, significant differences between the quaternary ammonium and quaternary phosphonium containing structures are apparent, which we attribute to the steric requirements of the countercations. In comparing the two major variants of the anionic [CuI­(F4­TCNQII–)]− networks, it is useful to consider edge-sharing strips composed of F4­TCNQ2– ligands surrounded by four Cu(I) centers. In Figure a and b, strips formed from rectangular [Cu4­(F4­TCNQII–)] units sharing long edges extend along directions parallel to both the a and the b axes. Figure a is a schematic representation showing part of an edge-sharing strip that appears in structures 1–4. If linear CCN-Cu links in addition to idealized β angles (see Figure a) of 120° were adopted, then an angle of 120° would be imposed upon the Cu(I) center. To at least partially satisfy Cu(I)’s preference for a regular tetrahedral geometry, the β angle opens up in structures 1–4 to a value in the range of 122.36(15)–123.0(2)°, which leads to a closing of the α angle from 120° to 114.0(5)–114.7(3)°. With a small degree of bending along the CCN-Cu connections, the N–Cu–N angles (corresponding to γ in Figure a) fall in the range of 107.4(2)–110.1(2)°, values that span the ideal tetrahedral angle of 109.5°.

elements.content: In structures 5 and 6, strips of the type depicted in Figure a are apparent with α angles in the range of 114.84(15)–116.5(2)°, β angles in the range of 120.86(2)–122.36(15)°, and γ angles in the range of 111.02(8)–111.35(2)°. In addition to the strips formed from long-edge-sharing rectangles, there are also strips formed in which the rectangles share short edges, as depicted in Figure b; these strips run vertically in Figures a and a and into the page in Figures b and b. The schematic representation indicates that, if an ideal α angle of 120° were adopted and the CCN-Cu connections were linear, then an angle of 60° would be imposed upon the Cu(I) center. To accommodate the Cu(I) center, two significant distortions from ideal geometries occur. First, the α angle closes up to a value in the range of 113.5(2)–114.0(2)°, and second, the angle at the coordinating nitrogen center shows a significant deviation from 180°. Even with these distortions, the δ angle at the Cu(I) center of 99.28(6)–99.32(6)° falls well short of the ideal tetrahedral angle. These results suggest that strips composed of [Cu4­(F4­TCNQII–)] rectangles that share long edges are significantly less strained (Figure a) than those that contain strips composed of [Cu4­(F4­TCNQII–)] rectangles that share short edges (Figure b).

In addition to the strips formed from long-edge-sharing rectangles, there are also strips formed in which the rectangles share short edges, as depicted in Figure b; these strips run vertically in Figures a and a and into the page in Figures b and b. elements.content: The family of structures reported in this current work provides examples of the ability of F4­TCNQ2– to act as a 4-connecting planar ligand within extended networks. In combination with Cu(I), PtS-related networks are formed with the relative orientations of the F4­TCNQ2– dependent upon the steric requirements of the countercation. These results raise the prospect of generating specific anionic networks by selecting appropriate countercations.
elements.clean_text:
Concluding Remarks

The family of structures reported in this current work provides examples of the ability of F4TCNQ2- to act as a 4-connecting planar ligand within extended networks. In combination with Cu(I), PtS-related networks are formed with the relative orientations of the F4TCNQ2- dependent upon the steric requirements of the countercation. These results raise the prospect of generating specific anionic networks by selecting appropriate countercations.

elements.content: Setting aside the potential redox activity of F4­TCNQ2–, the results of this investigation in addition to structural studies of TCNQ2–-based networks involving a range of metals indicate the versatility and suitability of TCNQ2– and F4­TCNQ2– in providing access to a rich variety of open network structures. It would seem that a wide range of structures based upon known structural prototypes, such as Pt3O4 and NbO, in which the dianion serves as a planar 4-connecting ligand, are realistic possibilities. As indicated in the , these results are in stark contrast to attempts to form open network materials when the TCNQ is neutral or present as the radical monoanion.
elements.clean_text: Setting aside the potential redox activity of F4TCNQ2-, the results of this investigation in addition to structural studies of TCNQ2--based networks involving a range of metals indicate the versatility and suitability of TCNQ2- and F4TCNQ2- in providing access to a rich variety of open network structures. It would seem that a wide range of structures based upon known structural prototypes, such as Pt3O4 and NbO, in which the dianion serves as a planar 4-connecting ligand, are realistic possibilities. As indicated in the , these results are in stark contrast to attempts to form open network materials when the TCNQ is neutral or present as the radical monoanion.

elements.content: The incorporation of the dianion form of the ligand into an infinite network offers the prospect of generating networks in which the ligand is in a monoanionic radical state or even neutral state by introducing oxidants into channels in a heterogeneous process and partially oxidizing the network. Such a process may lead to the generation of solids with unusual electronic or magnetic properties.

Such a process may lead to the generation of solids with unusual electronic or magnetic properties.

cln_elements.content:
F4­TCNQ­H2 (IIIb) was prepared according to the literature method.

Synthesis of NMe<sub>4</sub>­[Cu<sup>I</sup>­(F<sub>4</sub>­TCNQ<sup>II–</sup>) (<bold>1</bold>), NMe<sub>2</sub>­Pr<sub>2</sub>­[Cu<sup>I</sup>­(F<sub>4</sub>­TCNQ<sup>II–</sup>)] (<bold>2</bold>), NMe<sub>2</sub>­Bu<sub>2</sub>­[Cu<sup>I</sup>­(F<sub>4</sub>­TCNQ<sup>II–</sup>)] (<bold>3</bold>), and NEt<sub>4</sub>­[Cu<sup>I</sup>­(F<sub>4</sub>­TCNQ<sup>II–</sup>)] (<bold>4</bold>)

Compound 1 was prepared by dissolving [Cu­(Me­CN)4]­ClO4 (15.3 mg, 0.047 mmol) in MeCN (3 mL) and mixing this with a solution of Li­(OAc)·2H2O (82.5 mg, 0.81 mmol) and tetramethylammonium bromide (72.3 mg, 0.47 mmol) in EtOH (3 mL). The solution was then allowed to slowly diffuse into a solution of F4­TCNQ­H2 (13 mg, 0.047 mmol) in DMSO (1 mL). Crystals for single-crystal analysis were transferred directly from the mother liquor to a protective oil. The product was filtered and air-dried. Yield: 5.5 mg, 28%. IR (KBr): 2184, 2148, 1491, 1233, 1146, 962, 794, 544 cm–1. Anal. Calcd for C16H15­CuF4­N5O0.5 (1·0.5 H2O): C, 45.45; H, 3.10; N, 16.56. Found: C, 45.22; H, 3.24; N, 16.45%. Compounds 2, 3, and 4 were prepared via a similar method, but with 0.47 mmol of the appropriate tetraalkylammonium salt. Yield of 2: 2.7 mg, 12%. IR (KBr): 2185, 2147, 1486, 1231, 1143, 962, 792, 542 cm–1. Anal. Calcd for C20H20­CuF4­N5 (2): C, 51.12; H, 4.29; N, 14.90. Found: C, 50.78; H, 4.41; N, 14.62%. Yield of 3: 5.5 mg, 24%. IR (KBr): 2187, 2154, 1485, 1232, 1142, 961, 792, 540 cm–1. Anal. Calcd for C22H24­CuF4­N5 (3) C, 53.06; H, 4.86; N, 14.06. Found: C, 53.04; H, 5.05; N, 14.03%. Yield of 4·H2O: 2.5 mg, 11%. IR (KBr): 2178, 2135, 1487, 1224, 1147, 961, 791, 550 cm–1. Anal. Calcd for C20H22­CuF4­N5O (4·H2O) C, 49.22; H, 4.54; N, 14.35. Found: C, 48.94; H, 3.85; N, 14.29%.

Synthesis of PPh<sub>4</sub>­[Cu<sup>I</sup>­(F<sub>4</sub>TCNQ<sup>II–</sup>)] (<bold>5</bold>)

A solution of [Cu­(MeCN)4]­ClO4 (15.3 mg, 0.047 mmol) in MeCN (3 mL) was mixed with a solution of PPh4­Br (195 mg, 0.47 mmol) and 2,6-lutidine (0.1 mL) in MeOH (3 mL). This solution was diffused slowly into a solution of F4­TCNQ­H2 (13 mg, 0.047 mmol) in DMF (1 mL), yielding large green crystals. The product was filtered and air-dried. Yield: 10.0 mg, 30%. IR (KBr): 2188, 2156, 1486, 1233, 1142, 962, 723, 527 cm–1. Anal. Calcd for (5·0.5DMF) C37.5H23.5­CuF4­N5.5O0.5­P: C, 62.94; H, 3.31; N, 8.81%. Found: C, 62.43; H, 3.33; N, 8.92%.

Synthesis of PMe­Ph<sub>3</sub>­[Cu<sup>I</sup>­(F<sub>4</sub>­TCNQ<sup>II–</sup>)](<bold>6</bold>)

A solution of [Cu­(MeCN)4]­ClO4 (15.3 mg, 0.047 mmol) in PhCN (1 mL) was mixed with a solution of Li­(OAc)·2H2O (82.5 mg, 0.81 mmol) and PPh3­Me­Br (167 mg, 0.47 mmol) in MeOH (4 mL). This solution was diffused slowly into a solution of F4­TCNQ­H2 (13 mg, 0.047 mmol) in DMF (1 mL), yielding large yellow crystals. The product was filtered and air-dried. Yield: 12.4 mg, 41%. IR (KBr): 2204, 2163, 2137, 1489, 1247, 1150, 964, 801, 542 cm–1. Anal. Calcd for (6·0.5DMF) C32.5H21.5­CuF4­N4.5O0.5­P: C, 59.73; H, 3.32; N, 9.72%. Found C, 59.38; H 3.29; N, 9.84%.

Synthesis of F4TCNQH2 

F4TCNQH2 (IIIb) was prepared according to the literature method. 

Synthesis of NMe4[CuI(F4TCNQII-) (1), NMe2Pr2[CuI(F4TCNQII-)] (2), NMe2Bu2[CuI(F4TCNQII-)] (3), and NEt4[CuI(F4TCNQII-)] (4)

Compound 1 was prepared by dissolving [Cu(MeCN)4]ClO4 (15.3 mg, 0.047 mmol) in MeCN (3 mL) and mixing this with a solution of Li(OAc)⋅2H2O (82.5 mg, 0.81 mmol) and tetramethylammonium bromide (72.3 mg, 0.47 mmol) in EtOH (3 mL). The solution was then allowed to slowly diffuse into a solution of F4TCNQH2 (13 mg, 0.047 mmol) in DMSO (1 mL). Crystals for single-crystal analysis were transferred directly from the mother liquor to a protective oil. The product was filtered and air-dried. Yield: 5.5 mg, 28%. IR (KBr): 2184, 2148, 1491, 1233, 1146, 962, 794, 544 cm-1. Anal. Calcd for C16H15CuF4N5O0.5 (1⋅0.5 H2O): C, 45.45; H, 3.10; N, 16.56. Found: C, 45.22; H, 3.24; N, 16.45%. Compounds 2, 3, and 4 were prepared via a similar method, but with 0.47 mmol of the appropriate tetraalkylammonium salt. Yield of 2: 2.7 mg, 12%. IR (KBr): 2185, 2147, 1486, 1231, 1143, 962, 792, 542 cm-1. Anal. Calcd for C20H20CuF4N5 (2): C, 51.12; H, 4.29; N, 14.90. Found: C, 50.78; H, 4.41; N, 14.62%. Yield of 3: 5.5 mg, 24%. IR (KBr): 2187, 2154, 1485, 1232, 1142, 961, 792, 540 cm-1. Anal. Calcd for C22H24CuF4N5 (3) C, 53.06; H, 4.86; N, 14.06. Found: C, 53.04; H, 5.05; N, 14.03%. Yield of 4⋅H2O: 2.5 mg, 11%. IR (KBr): 2178, 2135, 1487, 1224, 1147, 961, 791, 550 cm-1. Anal. Calcd for C20H22CuF4N5O (4⋅H2O) C, 49.22; H, 4.54; N, 14.35. Found: C, 48.94; H, 3.85; N, 14.29%.

Synthesis of PPh4[CuI(F4TCNQII-)] (5)

A solution of [Cu(MeCN)4]ClO4 (15.3 mg, 0.047 mmol) in MeCN (3 mL) was mixed with a solution of PPh4Br (195 mg, 0.47 mmol) and 2,6-lutidine (0.1 mL) in MeOH (3 mL). This solution was diffused slowly into a solution of F4TCNQH2 (13 mg, 0.047 mmol) in DMF (1 mL), yielding large green crystals. The product was filtered and air-dried. Yield: 10.0 mg, 30%. IR (KBr): 2188, 2156, 1486, 1233, 1142, 962, 723, 527 cm-1. Anal. Calcd for (5⋅0.5DMF) C37.5H23.5CuF4N5.5O0.5P: C, 62.94; H, 3.31; N, 8.81%. Found: C, 62.43; H, 3.33; N, 8.92%.

Synthesis of PMePh3[CuI(F4TCNQII-)](6)

A solution of [Cu(MeCN)4]ClO4 (15.3 mg, 0.047 mmol) in PhCN (1 mL) was mixed with a solution of Li(OAc)⋅2H2O (82.5 mg, 0.81 mmol) and PPh3MeBr (167 mg, 0.47 mmol) in MeOH (4 mL). This solution was diffused slowly into a solution of F4TCNQH2 (13 mg, 0.047 mmol) in DMF (1 mL), yielding large yellow crystals. The product was filtered and air-dried. Yield: 12.4 mg, 41%. IR (KBr): 2204, 2163, 2137, 1489, 1247, 1150, 964, 801, 542 cm-1. Anal. Calcd for (6⋅0.5DMF) C32.5H21.5CuF4N4.5O0.5P: C, 59.73; H, 3.32; N, 9.72%. Found C, 59.38; H 3.29; N, 9.84%.

cln_elements.content: Structure of NMe4­[Cu­(F4­TCNQII–)]·0.5H2O (1·0.5H2O).
